question: Do CD28 co-stimulatory signals regulate the trafficking of self-reactive Ctla4-deficient T cells into target tissues in mice? Answer with Yes or No.

content.source_1: Here, we demonstrate that the CD28 co-stimulatory pathway regulates the trafficking of self-reactive Ctla4(-/-) T cells to tissues.
content.source_2: In adoptive transfer experiments using Ctla4(-/-) T cells, blockade or genetic deletion of CD28 altered activation thresholds but did not change tissue homing, with equivalent accumulation in target organs compared to controls at 24â€“72 hours post-transfer.
content.source_3: Ablation of the CD28-activated Tec kinase ITK caused self-reactive Ctla4(-/-) T cells to accumulate in secondary lymphoid organs rather than infiltrate non-lymphoid tissues, indicating a trafficking defect downstream of CD28 signaling.
content.source_4: In contrast, combined CD28 and ITK deficiency in the Ctla4(-/-) background increased pancreatic and hepatic infiltration by autoreactive T cells relative to single mutants, suggesting that CD28-dependent signals restrain, rather than promote, tissue entry.
